intro: Lepidium obovatum, commonly known as the broad-leaved peppergrass, is a flowering plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops such as cabbage and mustard. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, with basal leaves that are obovate in shape and covered in fine, branched hairs. Its small, white or pale yellow flowers are arranged in racemes and bloom from late spring to early summer. The seeds are small and contained within siliques, which are characteristic of the Brassicaceae family.
